elements.content: Four new metal–organic frameworks have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions by the self-assembly of a N-centered multidentate bifunctional ligand (H2L: 4,4′-((4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­azanediyl)­dibenzoic acid) with different N-containing heterocyclic coligands (BIMB = 4,4′-bis­((imidazol-1-yl)­methyl)­biphenyl, BPY = 4,4′-bipyridine, BIP = 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­phenyl) and transition metal salts (Co­(NO3)2·6H2O, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O). They are [Co­(L)­(BIMB)0.5­(H2O)]·2DMF (1), [Co­(L)­(BPY)0.5­(H2O)2]­·3DMF­·2H2O (2), [Zn2(L)2]­·4DMF­·3H2O (3), and [Zn2(L)2(BIP)]­·2DMF­·2H2O (4). Compound 1 is an infrequent 3,4-connected self-penetration three-dimensional (3D) architecture. Compound 2 has been classified as a trinodal (3,4,4)-connected 3D sqc69 framework. Compound 3 displays a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D net based on the [Zn2(CO2)4] units which are connected by L2– ligands. For compound 4, the larger potential voids lead to a 4-fold interpenetration, which can be classified as type IIIa. In addition, their thermal stability, the adsorption isotherms, and optical properties have been studied in detail.
elements.clean_text: Four new metal-organic frameworks have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions by the self-assembly of a N-centered multidentate bifunctional ligand (H2L: 4,4'-((4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)azanediyl)dibenzoic acid) with different N-containing heterocyclic coligands (BIMB = 4,4'-bis((imidazol-1-yl)methyl)biphenyl, BPY = 4,4'-bipyridine, BIP = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)phenyl) and transition metal salts (Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O). They are [Co(L)(BIMB)0.5(H2O)]⋅2DMF (1), [Co(L)(BPY)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3DMF⋅2H2O (2), [Zn2(L)2]⋅4DMF⋅3H2O (3), and [Zn2(L)2(BIP)]⋅2DMF⋅2H2O (4). Compound 1 is an infrequent 3,4-connected self-penetration three-dimensional (3D) architecture. Compound 2 has been classified as a trinodal (3,4,4)-connected 3D sqc69 framework. Compound 3 displays a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D net based on the [Zn2(CO2)4] units which are connected by L2- ligands. For compound 4, the larger potential voids lead to a 4-fold interpenetration, which can be classified as type IIIa. In addition, their thermal stability, the adsorption isotherms, and optical properties have been studied in detail.

elements.content: Four new metal−organic frameworks have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions based on the N-center pyridine-carboxylate bifunctional ligand. Compounds 1−4 show interesting self-penetration three-dimensional nets. In addition, compounds 3 and 4 can be used in gas separation of CO2 and CH4.
elements.clean_text: Four new metal-organic frameworks have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions based on the N-center pyridine-carboxylate bifunctional ligand. Compounds 1-4 show interesting self-penetration three-dimensional nets. In addition, compounds 3 and 4 can be used in gas separation of CO2 and CH4.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted tremendous research interest not only for their potential applications but also for their aesthetic topologies. However, it is still a challenge to exactly predict the structures of MOFs. The self-assembly of MOFs is influenced by many factors, such as organic ligands, metal ions, solvent systems, and temperature. Among these factors, the structural characteristics of polydentate organic ligands play an important role. Systematic studies of diverse ligands leading to different structures in the formation of coordination polymers are thus important and interesting.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted tremendous research interest not only for their potential applications but also for their aesthetic topologies. However, it is still a challenge to exactly predict the structures of MOFs. The self-assembly of MOFs is influenced by many factors, such as organic ligands, metal ions, solvent systems, and temperature. Among these factors, the structural characteristics of polydentate organic ligands play an important role. Systematic studies of diverse ligands leading to different structures in the formation of coordination polymers are thus important and interesting.

elements.content: Recently, our group has investigated a series of related research about N-centered triangular ligands in the fields of coordination polymers, and dozens of coordination polymers, with porosity, chirality, and aesthetic topology structures, have been reported. A prominent feature of the N-centered ligand is that the coordination sites can adjust their coordination orientation when coordinated groups rotate along the C–N bonds. Herein, the investigation on chemistry of pyridine-carboxylate N-centered bifunctional ligands has attracted our interest. A Co­(II)-based MOF with a new pyridine-carboxylate N-centered bifunctional ligand, 4,4′-((4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­azanediyl)­dibenzoic acid, had been reported earlier. As further exploitation of the study, four new MOFs with novel structures and various degrees of interpenetration, [Co­(L)­(BIMB)0.5­(H2O)]·2DMF (1), [Co­(L)­(BPY)0.5­(H2O)2]­·3DMF­·2H2O (2), [Zn2(L)2]­·4DMF­·3H2O (3), and [Zn2(L)2­(BIP)]­·2DMF­·2H2O (4), have been successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.
elements.clean_text: Recently, our group has investigated a series of related research about N-centered triangular ligands in the fields of coordination polymers, and dozens of coordination polymers, with porosity, chirality, and aesthetic topology structures, have been reported. A prominent feature of the N-centered ligand is that the coordination sites can adjust their coordination orientation when coordinated groups rotate along the C-N bonds. Herein, the investigation on chemistry of pyridine-carboxylate N-centered bifunctional ligands has attracted our interest. A Co(II)-based MOF with a new pyridine-carboxylate N-centered bifunctional ligand, 4,4'-((4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)azanediyl)dibenzoic acid, had been reported earlier. As further exploitation of the study, four new MOFs with novel structures and various degrees of interpenetration, [Co(L)(BIMB)0.5(H2O)]⋅2DMF (1), [Co(L)(BPY)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3DMF⋅2H2O (2), [Zn2(L)2]⋅4DMF⋅3H2O (3), and [Zn2(L)2(BIP)]⋅2DMF⋅2H2O (4), have been successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.

elements.clean_text: 1  New N-Centered Bifunctional Ligand H2L and N-Containing Heterocyclic Co-Ligands

elements.content: The reagents and solvents which we used were commercially available and did not need further purification. The elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out by a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. The IR absorption spectra of these coordination complexes were recorded in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 on a Nicolet Impact 410 infrared spectrometer by using KBr pellets. The crystal structures of these coordination complexes were measured by a Bruker Smart APEX CCD single-crystal diffractometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer, in which the Cu-tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA and used a graphite monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ is 0.71073 Å) as the photosource. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed by a PerkinElmer thermogravimetric analyzer Pyris 1 with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 under N2 atmosphere and heated from room temperature to 800 °C. Solid-state UV–vis absorption spectra were obtained at room temperature by using a Shimadzu UV-3600 double monochromator spectrophotometer, and BaSO4 was used as a 100% reflectance standard for all these coordination complexes. The solid-state fluorescence spectra were obtained at room temperature by using VF-320 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The gas absorption isotherms for compounds 3–4 were measured by a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 M + C surface area analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The reagents and solvents which we used were commercially available and did not need further purification. The elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out by a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. The IR absorption spectra of these coordination complexes were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Nicolet Impact 410 infrared spectrometer by using KBr pellets. The crystal structures of these coordination complexes were measured by a Bruker Smart APEX CCD single-crystal diffractometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer, in which the Cu-tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA and used a graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ is 0.71073 Å) as the photosource. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed by a PerkinElmer thermogravimetric analyzer Pyris 1 with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 under N2 atmosphere and heated from room temperature to 800 °C. Solid-state UV-vis absorption spectra were obtained at room temperature by using a Shimadzu UV-3600 double monochromator spectrophotometer, and BaSO4 was used as a 100% reflectance standard for all these coordination complexes. The solid-state fluorescence spectra were obtained at room temperature by using VF-320 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The gas absorption isotherms for compounds 3-4 were measured by a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 M + C surface area analyzer.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data of complexes 1–4 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker Smart APEX CCD single-crystal diffractometer by a way of sealing better single crystals in a quartz tube with mother liquor, which used ω-scan and a graphite monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ is 0.71073 Å) as the photosource. The intensity data were integrated by using the SAINT program. An empirical absorption correction were applied by using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by using direct method, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structures and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL-97 using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F2 values. The positions of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement factors. The hydrogen atoms were positioned geometrically by using a idealized riding model. The lattice DMF molecules were squeezed by the PLATON program. The crystallographic data of the complexes 1–4 are listed in . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S1–S4.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray crystallographic data of complexes 1-4 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker Smart APEX CCD single-crystal diffractometer by a way of sealing better single crystals in a quartz tube with mother liquor, which used ω-scan and a graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ is 0.71073 Å) as the photosource. The intensity data were integrated by using the SAINT program. An empirical absorption correction were applied by using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by using direct method, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structures and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL-97 using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F2 values. The positions of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement factors. The hydrogen atoms were positioned geometrically by using a idealized riding model. The lattice DMF molecules were squeezed by the PLATON program. The crystallographic data of the complexes 1-4 are listed in . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S1-S4.

wR 2 = {Σ­[w(F 0 2 – F c 2)2]/Σ­[w(F 0 2)2]}1/2; where w = 1/[σ2(F 0 2) + (aP)2 + bP], P = (F 0 2 + 2F c 2)/3.

In the present work, our group synthesized a Co-MOFs based on H2L. In the following work, we used different N-containing heterocyclic ligands as coligands to form novel structures and explore the effects of different coligands on the structures. Then we changed the central ions from Co­(II) to Zn­(II) to explore the effects of different central ions on the structures. We successfully synthesized four new MOFs, and their structures have been described in detail. The experimental section is listed in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structure

In the present work, our group synthesized a Co-MOFs based on H2L. In the following work, we used different N-containing heterocyclic ligands as coligands to form novel structures and explore the effects of different coligands on the structures. Then we changed the central ions from Co(II) to Zn(II) to explore the effects of different central ions on the structures. We successfully synthesized four new MOFs, and their structures have been described in detail. The experimental section is listed in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system and C2/c space group. In the asymmetric unit of 1, there are one independent Co­(II), one L2– ligand, one-half of BIMB ligand, one coordinated water molecule, and two lattice DMF molecules. (The lattice DMF molecules are squeezed by PLATON program because of disorder.) As shown in a, the Co1 is hexa-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from one BIMB ligand and one L2– ligand, one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule, as well as three carboxylic oxygen atoms form two different L2– ligands. What is noteworthy is that the two carboxylic groups of L2– ligands manifest one bidentate chelate coordination mode and one monodentate coordination mode. The Co–N bond distances range from 2.081(3) to 2.117(3) Å, and the Co–O bonds range from 2.038(3) to 2.170(2) Å, which are comparable with reported distances of Co–N/O for octahedral compounds. The Co­(II) cations are connected by the carboxylic groups to form one-dimensional (1D) chains which are composed of [Co2(L)2] repetitive units. The 1D chains are connected by the N atoms of L2– ligands to form a three-dimensional (3D) framework, which has been shown in b. Then two identical 3D frameworks were further connected by BIMB ligands to form a self-penetration 3D framework, which has been shown in c.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Crystal Structure of [Co(L)(BIMB)0.5(H2O)]⋅2DMF (1)

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system and C2/c space group. In the asymmetric unit of 1, there are one independent Co(II), one L2- ligand, one-half of BIMB ligand, one coordinated water molecule, and two lattice DMF molecules. (The lattice DMF molecules are squeezed by PLATON program because of disorder.) As shown in a, the Co1 is hexa-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from one BIMB ligand and one L2- ligand, one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule, as well as three carboxylic oxygen atoms form two different L2- ligands. What is noteworthy is that the two carboxylic groups of L2- ligands manifest one bidentate chelate coordination mode and one monodentate coordination mode. The Co-N bond distances range from 2.081(3) to 2.117(3) Å, and the Co-O bonds range from 2.038(3) to 2.170(2) Å, which are comparable with reported distances of Co-N/O for octahedral compounds. The Co(II) cations are connected by the carboxylic groups to form one-dimensional (1D) chains which are composed of [Co2(L)2] repetitive units. The 1D chains are connected by the N atoms of L2- ligands to form a three-dimensional (3D) framework, which has been shown in b. Then two identical 3D frameworks were further connected by BIMB ligands to form a self-penetration 3D framework, which has been shown in c.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP drawing of 1 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity), symmetry codes: #1= 1 – x, y, 1.5 – z; #2 = x, 1 – y, 0.5 + z; #3 = 0.5 + x, 1.5 – y, 0.5 + z. (b) Perspective of the 3D framework formed by Co2+ ions and L2– ligands along the b axis. (c) Perspective of the 3D framework 1 along the b axis. (d) Schematic representation of a self-penetrating crs topology framework of compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) ORTEP drawing of 1 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity), symmetry codes: #1= 1 - x, y, 1.5 - z; #2 = x, 1 - y, 0.5 + z; #3 = 0.5 + x, 1.5 - y, 0.5 + z. (b) Perspective of the 3D framework formed by Co2+ ions and L2- ligands along the b axis. (c) Perspective of the 3D framework 1 along the b axis. (d) Schematic representation of a self-penetrating crs topology framework of compound 1.

elements.content: By using a topological approach which can reduce multidimensional structures to simple node-and-link frameworks, we can achieve a better insight about the framework nature of compound 1. Each L2– ligand linking three Co­(II) cations can be considered as a 3-connected node; therefore the frameworks can be simplified as a 2-fold interpenetration ths 3-connected topology, regardless of the BIMB ligands. The two ths frameworks are further cross-linked by BIMB linker to form a self-penetrating crs-d-3,4-I41/amd (it is a subnet of the net crs) 2-nodal 3,4-connected topology which has the point symbol of {62·8}­{63·8·102} (d).
elements.clean_text: By using a topological approach which can reduce multidimensional structures to simple node-and-link frameworks, we can achieve a better insight about the framework nature of compound 1. Each L2- ligand linking three Co(II) cations can be considered as a 3-connected node; therefore the frameworks can be simplified as a 2-fold interpenetration ths 3-connected topology, regardless of the BIMB ligands. The two ths frameworks are further cross-linked by BIMB linker to form a self-penetrating crs-d-3,4-I41/amd (it is a subnet of the net crs) 2-nodal 3,4-connected topology which has the point symbol of {62⋅8}{63⋅8⋅102} (d).

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system and P1̅ space group. There are two halves Co­(II) cations, one L2– ligand, one-half of BPY ligand, two coordinated water molecules, three lattice DMF molecules, and two lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit of 2. As shown in a, the Co1 and Co2 both are hexa-coordinated. Co1 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two different L2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two different BPY ligands, as well as two oxygen atoms from the coordinated water molecules. Co2 is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms from four different L2– ligands, respectively, and two oxygen atoms from the coordinated water molecules. All carboxylic groups of L2– ligands manifest monodentate coordination mode. Both Co­(II) atoms exist in a distorted octahedral environment. The Co–N bond distances range from 2.117(3) to 2.178(2) Å, and the Co–O bonds range from 2.042(18) to 2.115(2) Å, which are within reasonable range. The Co­(II) cations are connected by the L2– ligands to generate a 2D layer (b). The 2D layers are connected by the BPY ligands to form a 3D framework, which has been shown in c.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Co(L)(BPY)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3DMF⋅2H2O (2)

Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system and P1̅ space group. There are two halves Co(II) cations, one L2- ligand, one-half of BPY ligand, two coordinated water molecules, three lattice DMF molecules, and two lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit of 2. As shown in a, the Co1 and Co2 both are hexa-coordinated. Co1 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two different L2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two different BPY ligands, as well as two oxygen atoms from the coordinated water molecules. Co2 is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms from four different L2- ligands, respectively, and two oxygen atoms from the coordinated water molecules. All carboxylic groups of L2- ligands manifest monodentate coordination mode. Both Co(II) atoms exist in a distorted octahedral environment. The Co-N bond distances range from 2.117(3) to 2.178(2) Å, and the Co-O bonds range from 2.042(18) to 2.115(2) Å, which are within reasonable range. The Co(II) cations are connected by the L2- ligands to generate a 2D layer (b). The 2D layers are connected by the BPY ligands to form a 3D framework, which has been shown in c.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP drawing of 2 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity), symmetry codes: #1 = 2 – x, – y, −z; #2 = 1 – x, −y, 2 – z; #3 = 1 – x, 1 – y, −z; #4 = −1 + x, 1 + y, z. (b) Perspective of 2D layer formed by Co2+ ions and L2– ligands along the a axis. (c) Perspective of 3D framework 2 along the a axis. (d) A view of a single sqc69 framework of compound 2. (e) Schematic representation of 2-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks of compound 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) ORTEP drawing of 2 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity), symmetry codes: #1 = 2 - x, - y, -z; #2 = 1 - x, -y, 2 - z; #3 = 1 - x, 1 - y, -z; #4 = -1 + x, 1 + y, z. (b) Perspective of 2D layer formed by Co2+ ions and L2- ligands along the a axis. (c) Perspective of 3D framework 2 along the a axis. (d) A view of a single sqc69 framework of compound 2. (e) Schematic representation of 2-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks of compound 2.

elements.content: By reducing multidimensional structures to simple nodes, each L2– ligand linking three Co­(II) cations can be considered as a 3-connected node, and the two Co­(II) cations can be regarded as 4-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a sqc69 3-nodal (3,4,4)-connected topology which has the point symbol of {4·82}­{42·82·102}­{8·104·12} (d). There are two different 1D channels existing along the a axes in the single framework. There are 23.62 Å × 10.42 and 9.30 Å × 9.13 Å. The potential voids are large enough to be filled by an independent identical framework and generate a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure (e).
elements.clean_text: By reducing multidimensional structures to simple nodes, each L2- ligand linking three Co(II) cations can be considered as a 3-connected node, and the two Co(II) cations can be regarded as 4-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a sqc69 3-nodal (3,4,4)-connected topology which has the point symbol of {4⋅82}{42⋅82⋅102}{8⋅104⋅12} (d). There are two different 1D channels existing along the a axes in the single framework. There are 23.62 Å × 10.42 and 9.30 Å × 9.13 Å. The potential voids are large enough to be filled by an independent identical framework and generate a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure (e).

elements.content: The crystal data analysis indicates that compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system and P21/c space group. In the minimum asymmetric unit of 3, there are two independent Zn­(II) cations, two L2– ligands, and four lattice DMF molecules, and three lattice water molecules. As shown in a, each Zn­(II) cation is coordinated by one nitrogen atom and four oxygen atoms from five different L2– ligands. These coordination atoms form a distorted tetragonal pyramid that the four oxygen atoms constitute the basal plane and the nitrogen atom in the axial position. The distances of Zn–N bonds range from 2.030(2) to 2.035(3) Å, and the Zn–O bonds range from 2.012(18) to 2.093(2) Å, which are comparable with reported distances of Zn–N/O in the literature. All carboxylic groups of L2– ligands manifest a bidentate bridged coordination mode and link the two adjacent Zn­(II) cations to form a “paddle-wheel” secondary building unit that has been identified as [Zn2(CO2)4]; the distance of Zn–Zn among that is 2.9447(4) Å. These secondary building units are connected by the L2– ligands to generate a two-dimensional (2D) layer, regardless of the coordinate nitrogen atom. The 2D layers are connected by the N atoms of L2– ligands to form a 3D framework, which is shown in b. There are 1D channels existing along the a axes in the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Zn2(L)2]⋅4DMF⋅3H2O (3)

The crystal data analysis indicates that compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system and P21/c space group. In the minimum asymmetric unit of 3, there are two independent Zn(II) cations, two L2- ligands, and four lattice DMF molecules, and three lattice water molecules. As shown in a, each Zn(II) cation is coordinated by one nitrogen atom and four oxygen atoms from five different L2- ligands. These coordination atoms form a distorted tetragonal pyramid that the four oxygen atoms constitute the basal plane and the nitrogen atom in the axial position. The distances of Zn-N bonds range from 2.030(2) to 2.035(3) Å, and the Zn-O bonds range from 2.012(18) to 2.093(2) Å, which are comparable with reported distances of Zn-N/O in the literature. All carboxylic groups of L2- ligands manifest a bidentate bridged coordination mode and link the two adjacent Zn(II) cations to form a "paddle-wheel" secondary building unit that has been identified as [Zn2(CO2)4]; the distance of Zn-Zn among that is 2.9447(4) Å. These secondary building units are connected by the L2- ligands to generate a two-dimensional (2D) layer, regardless of the coordinate nitrogen atom. The 2D layers are connected by the N atoms of L2- ligands to form a 3D framework, which is shown in b. There are 1D channels existing along the a axes in the framework.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP drawing of 3 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity), symmetry codes: #1 = −1 + x, 1.5 – y, −0.5 + z; #2 = x, 1.5 – y, −0.5 + z; #3 = 1 + x, y, z; #4 = x, 0.5 – y, −0.5 + z. (b) Perspective of the 3D framework 3 along the a axis. (c) A view of a single rtl framework of compound 3. (d) Schematic representation of 2-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks of compound 3.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) ORTEP drawing of 3 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity), symmetry codes: #1 = -1 + x, 1.5 - y, -0.5 + z; #2 = x, 1.5 - y, -0.5 + z; #3 = 1 + x, y, z; #4 = x, 0.5 - y, -0.5 + z. (b) Perspective of the 3D framework 3 along the a axis. (c) A view of a single rtl framework of compound 3. (d) Schematic representation of 2-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks of compound 3.

elements.content: By using a topological approach, the secondary building units can be simplified to 6-connected nodes, and the L2– ligands which have two different spatial orientations can be regarded as 3-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a rtl 2-nodal 3,6-connected topology which has the point symbol of {4·62}­2­{42·610·83} (c). Because the potential voids are large enough to be filled by an independent identical framework, as shown in d, this compound finally generates a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure. It contains a solvent accessible void area of 43.6% which is calculated by the SOLV program of PLATON.
elements.clean_text: By using a topological approach, the secondary building units can be simplified to 6-connected nodes, and the L2- ligands which have two different spatial orientations can be regarded as 3-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a rtl 2-nodal 3,6-connected topology which has the point symbol of {4⋅62}2{42⋅610⋅83} (c). Because the potential voids are large enough to be filled by an independent identical framework, as shown in d, this compound finally generates a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure. It contains a solvent accessible void area of 43.6% which is calculated by the SOLV program of PLATON.

elements.content: The crystal data analysis indicates that compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system and P21/c space group. In the asymmetric unit of 4, there are two Zn­(II) cations, two L2– ligands, two halves of BIP ligands, two lattice water molecules, and two lattice DMF molecules. (The lattice DMF molecules are squeezed by PLATON program because of disorder.) As shown in a, the Zn1 and Zn2 are both five-coordinated. The Zn1 is coordinated by one nitrogen atom and three oxygen atoms from three different L2– ligands, as well as one nitrogen atom from the BIP ligand. The Zn2 is coordinated by one nitrogen atom and two oxygen atoms from three different L2– ligands, as well as one nitrogen atom from the BIP ligand. It is worth noting that in the L2– ligand two carboxylic groups manifest one bidentate chelate coordination mode and one monodentate coordination mode. In this structure, the distances of Zn–N bonds range from 2.006(3) to 2.073(2) Å, which is at reasonable range. The distances between Zn1 and the two O atoms of carboxylic group with bidentate chelate coordination modes are 2.1439(39) and 2.249(2) Å, while the distances between Zn2 and the two O atoms of carboxylic group with bidentate chelate coordination modes are 2.0546(22) and 2.4288(31) Å. The Zn­(II) cations are connected by the L2– ligands to generate a 2D layer (b). The 2D layers are connected by the BIP ligands to form a 3D framework, which has been shown in c. There are large 1D channels existing along the a axes in the single framework which is 23.84 Å × 21.01 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Zn2(L)2(BIP)]⋅2DMF⋅2H2O(4)

The crystal data analysis indicates that compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system and P21/c space group. In the asymmetric unit of 4, there are two Zn(II) cations, two L2- ligands, two halves of BIP ligands, two lattice water molecules, and two lattice DMF molecules. (The lattice DMF molecules are squeezed by PLATON program because of disorder.) As shown in a, the Zn1 and Zn2 are both five-coordinated. The Zn1 is coordinated by one nitrogen atom and three oxygen atoms from three different L2- ligands, as well as one nitrogen atom from the BIP ligand. The Zn2 is coordinated by one nitrogen atom and two oxygen atoms from three different L2- ligands, as well as one nitrogen atom from the BIP ligand. It is worth noting that in the L2- ligand two carboxylic groups manifest one bidentate chelate coordination mode and one monodentate coordination mode. In this structure, the distances of Zn-N bonds range from 2.006(3) to 2.073(2) Å, which is at reasonable range. The distances between Zn1 and the two O atoms of carboxylic group with bidentate chelate coordination modes are 2.1439(39) and 2.249(2) Å, while the distances between Zn2 and the two O atoms of carboxylic group with bidentate chelate coordination modes are 2.0546(22) and 2.4288(31) Å. The Zn(II) cations are connected by the L2- ligands to generate a 2D layer (b). The 2D layers are connected by the BIP ligands to form a 3D framework, which has been shown in c. There are large 1D channels existing along the a axes in the single framework which is 23.84 Å × 21.01 Å.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP drawing of 4 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity), symmetry codes: #1 = 1 + x, 1 + y, z; #2 = 1 + x, y, z; #3= 3 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z; #4= 2 – x, 1 – y, 3 – z. (b) Perspective of 2D layer formed by Zn2+ ions and L2– ligands along the a axis. (c) Perspective of 3D framework 4 along the a axis. (d) A view of a single ins framework of compound 4. (e) Schematic representation of 4-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks of compound 4.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) ORTEP drawing of 4 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity), symmetry codes: #1 = 1 + x, 1 + y, z; #2 = 1 + x, y, z; #3= 3 - x, 2 - y, 1 - z; #4= 2 - x, 1 - y, 3 - z. (b) Perspective of 2D layer formed by Zn2+ ions and L2- ligands along the a axis. (c) Perspective of 3D framework 4 along the a axis. (d) A view of a single ins framework of compound 4. (e) Schematic representation of 4-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks of compound 4.

elements.content: Each Zn­(II) cation has been linked to four other ligands so that it can be simplified to a 4-connected node by using a topological approach. And the L2– ligands can be regarded as 3-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a 2-nodal 3,4-connected ins topology which has the point symbol of {63}­{65·8} (d). Because of the larger potential voids, this compound finally generates a 4-fold interpenetrating 3D structure (e). It can be classified as type IIIa, Z = 4[2 × 2] (Z t = 2; Z n = 2). Although it has a 4-fold interpenetration, it still contains a solvent accessible void area of 34.7% calculated by the SOLV program of PLATON.
elements.clean_text: Each Zn(II) cation has been linked to four other ligands so that it can be simplified to a 4-connected node by using a topological approach. And the L2- ligands can be regarded as 3-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a 2-nodal 3,4-connected ins topology which has the point symbol of {63}{65⋅8} (d). Because of the larger potential voids, this compound finally generates a 4-fold interpenetrating 3D structure (e). It can be classified as type IIIa, Z = 4[2 × 2] (Z t = 2; Z n = 2). Although it has a 4-fold interpenetration, it still contains a solvent accessible void area of 34.7% calculated by the SOLV program of PLATON.

elements.content: The solid-state UV–vis absorption spectra of the H2L, BIMB, BPY, compounds 1 and 2 were obtained at room temperature. As can be seen in the UV–vis absorption spectra (Figure S2), the first absorption bands of compounds 1 and 2 ranging from 260 to 400 nm can be ascribed to π–π* and n−π* transitions of the ligands, and the second absorption bands ranging from 300 to 500 nm can be ascribed to MLCT. These two absorption bands overlap partially. The lower energy bands (500–650 nm for compound 1 and 500–600 nm for compound 2) are the characteristic absorption peaks of Co­(II) complexes which have d7 electronic configuration.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties

Solid-State UV-vis Absorption Spectra

The solid-state UV-vis absorption spectra of the H2L, BIMB, BPY, compounds 1 and 2 were obtained at room temperature. As can be seen in the UV-vis absorption spectra (Figure S2), the first absorption bands of compounds 1 and 2 ranging from 260 to 400 nm can be ascribed to π-π* and n-π* transitions of the ligands, and the second absorption bands ranging from 300 to 500 nm can be ascribed to MLCT. These two absorption bands overlap partially. The lower energy bands (500-650 nm for compound 1 and 500-600 nm for compound 2) are the characteristic absorption peaks of Co(II) complexes which have d7 electronic configuration.

elements.content: The solid-state fluorescence spectra of the H2L, BIP, compounds 3 and 4 were obtained at room temperature. The maximum excitation wavelengths and the maximum emission wavelengths are shown in Table S5 and Figure S3. The maximum emission peak of the H2L is at 530 nm which can be ascribed to π*−π or π*–n transitions. Compared with the maximum emission peak of free H2L ligand, a slight blue-shift about 8 nm can be found for compound 3. The emission spectrum of compound 3 is similar to the spectra of H2L; therefore, the emission of 3 can be attributed to the charge transfer within the H2L ligands. The maximum emission peak of compound 4 has an obvious blue-shift about 36 nm compared with compound 3. This is a reasonable speculation that the existence of ligand BIP results in reducing the coplanarity of phenyl rings.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Fluorescence Spectra

The solid-state fluorescence spectra of the H2L, BIP, compounds 3 and 4 were obtained at room temperature. The maximum excitation wavelengths and the maximum emission wavelengths are shown in Table S5 and Figure S3. The maximum emission peak of the H2L is at 530 nm which can be ascribed to π*-π or π*-n transitions. Compared with the maximum emission peak of free H2L ligand, a slight blue-shift about 8 nm can be found for compound 3. The emission spectrum of compound 3 is similar to the spectra of H2L; therefore, the emission of 3 can be attributed to the charge transfer within the H2L ligands. The maximum emission peak of compound 4 has an obvious blue-shift about 36 nm compared with compound 3. This is a reasonable speculation that the existence of ligand BIP results in reducing the coplanarity of phenyl rings.

elements.content: The powder diffraction patterns of compounds 1–4 are given by Figure S4 in order to confirm the purities. The experimental PXRD patterns and the simulated PXRD patterns match perfectly, which indicates that the compounds are pure phase.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

The powder diffraction patterns of compounds 1-4 are given by Figure S4 in order to confirm the purities. The experimental PXRD patterns and the simulated PXRD patterns match perfectly, which indicates that the compounds are pure phase.

elements.content: In order to characterize the thermostability of the frameworks, their thermal behaviors were measured by using TGA (Figure S5). A weight loss of 18.50% (calcd. 18.54%) from 45 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 1, which can be attributed to the release of two lattice DMF molecules. The frameworks are stable until 410 °C, and then the structure starts collapse. The reason may be that the release of the coordinated water molecule results in structure instability. A weight loss of 30.56% (calcd. 30.51%) from 45 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 2, which can be attributed to the release of all lattice molecules. The framework is unstable when all lattice molecules were released and starts collapse. A weight loss of 23.62% (calcd. 23.50%) from 45 to 250 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 3, which can be attributed to the release of four lattice DMF molecules. The frameworks start collapse at 360 °C. (When we performed TGA for compound 3, it had been prepared for a long time, and the three lattice water molecules had already been released.) A weight loss of 13.51% (calcd. 13.60%) from 50 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 4, which can be attributed to the release of two lattice DMF molecules and two lattice water molecules. The frameworks start collapse at 360 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA)

In order to characterize the thermostability of the frameworks, their thermal behaviors were measured by using TGA (Figure S5). A weight loss of 18.50% (calcd. 18.54%) from 45 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 1, which can be attributed to the release of two lattice DMF molecules. The frameworks are stable until 410 °C, and then the structure starts collapse. The reason may be that the release of the coordinated water molecule results in structure instability. A weight loss of 30.56% (calcd. 30.51%) from 45 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 2, which can be attributed to the release of all lattice molecules. The framework is unstable when all lattice molecules were released and starts collapse. A weight loss of 23.62% (calcd. 23.50%) from 45 to 250 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 3, which can be attributed to the release of four lattice DMF molecules. The frameworks start collapse at 360 °C. (When we performed TGA for compound 3, it had been prepared for a long time, and the three lattice water molecules had already been released.) A weight loss of 13.51% (calcd. 13.60%) from 50 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 4, which can be attributed to the release of two lattice DMF molecules and two lattice water molecules. The frameworks start collapse at 360 °C.

elements.content: The adsorption and desorption isotherm of N2 were collected under 77 K to check the permanent porosity of compound 3. As shown in (left), compound 3 exhibits a typical type I adsorption isotherm and absorbs 237.8 cm3·g–1 N2 at 77 K which has a microporous characteristic. The BET surface area is 658.7 m2·g–1, and the Langmuir surface area is 980.6 m2·g–1. Low-pressure CH4 and CO2 uptake was also measured at 273 K. The reversible isotherms are shown in (right). Compound 3 can absorb 61 cm3 g–1 CO2 and 28 cm3·g–1 CH4 at 273 K and 850 mmHg. When the pressure is increased, the adsorption quantity of CO2 increases greater than the adsorption quantity of CH4. It indicates that compound 3 can be used in gas separation of CO2 and CH4. Low-pressure CH4 and CO2 uptake isotherms of , the adsorption quantity of CO2 and the adsorption quantity of CH4 are 46.6 cm3·g–1 (273 K and 850 mmHg) and 9.8 cm3·g–1 (273 K and 850 mmHg), respectively. The difference value between these two gas uptakes is bigger, which illustrates compound 4 is more suitable for gas separation of CO2 and CH4 than compound 3.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Uptake Properties

The adsorption and desorption isotherm of N2 were collected under 77 K to check the permanent porosity of compound 3. As shown in  (left), compound 3 exhibits a typical type I adsorption isotherm and absorbs 237.8 cm3⋅g-1 N2 at 77 K which has a microporous characteristic. The BET surface area is 658.7 m2⋅g-1, and the Langmuir surface area is 980.6 m2⋅g-1. Low-pressure CH4 and CO2 uptake was also measured at 273 K. The reversible isotherms are shown in  (right). Compound 3 can absorb 61 cm3 g-1 CO2 and 28 cm3⋅g-1 CH4 at 273 K and 850 mmHg. When the pressure is increased, the adsorption quantity of CO2 increases greater than the adsorption quantity of CH4. It indicates that compound 3 can be used in gas separation of CO2 and CH4. Low-pressure CH4 and CO2 uptake isotherms of , the adsorption quantity of CO2 and the adsorption quantity of CH4 are 46.6 cm3⋅g-1 (273 K and 850 mmHg) and 9.8 cm3⋅g-1 (273 K and 850 mmHg), respectively. The difference value between these two gas uptakes is bigger, which illustrates compound 4 is more suitable for gas separation of CO2 and CH4 than compound 3.

elements.content: In conclusion, four new MOFs have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions based on the N-center pyridine-carboxylate bifunctional ligand. Compound 1 shows a self-penetration 3D framework. Compound 2 shows a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D net with a large 1D channel along the a-axes. Compound 3 manifests a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D framework based on the [Zn2(CO2)4] unit. Compound 4 manifests a 4-fold interpenetrating 3D structure because of large potential voids. In addition, compound 3 exhibits microporous absorption for N2, and both compounds 3 and 4 can be used in gas separation of CO2 and CH4.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, four new MOFs have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions based on the N-center pyridine-carboxylate bifunctional ligand. Compound 1 shows a self-penetration 3D framework. Compound 2 shows a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D net with a large 1D channel along the a-axes. Compound 3 manifests a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D framework based on the [Zn2(CO2)4] unit. Compound 4 manifests a 4-fold interpenetrating 3D structure because of large potential voids. In addition, compound 3 exhibits microporous absorption for N2, and both compounds 3 and 4 can be used in gas separation of CO2 and CH4.

These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif, or by emailing data_request@ccdc.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12, Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: +44 1223 336033.

cln_elements.content:
By reducing multidimensional structures to simple nodes, each L2– ligand linking three Co­(II) cations can be considered as a 3-connected node, and the two Co­(II) cations can be regarded as 4-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a sqc69 3-nodal (3,4,4)-connected topology which has the point symbol of {4·82}­{42·82·102}­{8·104·12} (d). There are two different 1D channels existing along the a axes in the single framework. There are 23.62 Å × 10.42 and 9.30 Å × 9.13 Å. The potential voids are large enough to be filled by an independent identical framework and generate a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure (e).

By using a topological approach, the secondary building units can be simplified to 6-connected nodes, and the L2– ligands which have two different spatial orientations can be regarded as 3-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a rtl 2-nodal 3,6-connected topology which has the point symbol of {4·62}­2­{42·610·83} (c). Because the potential voids are large enough to be filled by an independent identical framework, as shown in d, this compound finally generates a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure. It contains a solvent accessible void area of 43.6% which is calculated by the SOLV program of PLATON.

Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA)

In order to characterize the thermostability of the frameworks, their thermal behaviors were measured by using TGA (Figure S5). A weight loss of 18.50% (calcd. 18.54%) from 45 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 1, which can be attributed to the release of two lattice DMF molecules. The frameworks are stable until 410 °C, and then the structure starts collapse. The reason may be that the release of the coordinated water molecule results in structure instability. A weight loss of 30.56% (calcd. 30.51%) from 45 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 2, which can be attributed to the release of all lattice molecules. The framework is unstable when all lattice molecules were released and starts collapse. A weight loss of 23.62% (calcd. 23.50%) from 45 to 250 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 3, which can be attributed to the release of four lattice DMF molecules. The frameworks start collapse at 360 °C. (When we performed TGA for compound 3, it had been prepared for a long time, and the three lattice water molecules had already been released.) A weight loss of 13.51% (calcd. 13.60%) from 50 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 4, which can be attributed to the release of two lattice DMF molecules and two lattice water molecules. The frameworks start collapse at 360 °C.

Gas Uptake Properties

The adsorption and desorption isotherm of N2 were collected under 77 K to check the permanent porosity of compound 3. As shown in (left), compound 3 exhibits a typical type I adsorption isotherm and absorbs 237.8 cm3·g–1 N2 at 77 K which has a microporous characteristic. The BET surface area is 658.7 m2·g–1, and the Langmuir surface area is 980.6 m2·g–1. Low-pressure CH4 and CO2 uptake was also measured at 273 K. The reversible isotherms are shown in (right). Compound 3 can absorb 61 cm3 g–1 CO2 and 28 cm3·g–1 CH4 at 273 K and 850 mmHg. When the pressure is increased, the adsorption quantity of CO2 increases greater than the adsorption quantity of CH4. It indicates that compound 3 can be used in gas separation of CO2 and CH4. Low-pressure CH4 and CO2 uptake isotherms of , the adsorption quantity of CO2 and the adsorption quantity of CH4 are 46.6 cm3·g–1 (273 K and 850 mmHg) and 9.8 cm3·g–1 (273 K and 850 mmHg), respectively. The difference value between these two gas uptakes is bigger, which illustrates compound 4 is more suitable for gas separation of CO2 and CH4 than compound 3.

By reducing multidimensional structures to simple nodes, each L2- ligand linking three Co(II) cations can be considered as a 3-connected node, and the two Co(II) cations can be regarded as 4-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a sqc69 3-nodal (3,4,4)-connected topology which has the point symbol of {4⋅82}{42⋅82⋅102}{8⋅104⋅12} (d). There are two different 1D channels existing along the a axes in the single framework. There are 23.62 Å × 10.42 and 9.30 Å × 9.13 Å. The potential voids are large enough to be filled by an independent identical framework and generate a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure (e).

By using a topological approach, the secondary building units can be simplified to 6-connected nodes, and the L2- ligands which have two different spatial orientations can be regarded as 3-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be regarded as a rtl 2-nodal 3,6-connected topology which has the point symbol of {4⋅62}2{42⋅610⋅83} (c). Because the potential voids are large enough to be filled by an independent identical framework, as shown in d, this compound finally generates a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure. It contains a solvent accessible void area of 43.6% which is calculated by the SOLV program of PLATON.

Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA)

In order to characterize the thermostability of the frameworks, their thermal behaviors were measured by using TGA (Figure S5). A weight loss of 18.50% (calcd. 18.54%) from 45 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 1, which can be attributed to the release of two lattice DMF molecules. The frameworks are stable until 410 °C, and then the structure starts collapse. The reason may be that the release of the coordinated water molecule results in structure instability. A weight loss of 30.56% (calcd. 30.51%) from 45 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 2, which can be attributed to the release of all lattice molecules. The framework is unstable when all lattice molecules were released and starts collapse. A weight loss of 23.62% (calcd. 23.50%) from 45 to 250 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 3, which can be attributed to the release of four lattice DMF molecules. The frameworks start collapse at 360 °C. (When we performed TGA for compound 3, it had been prepared for a long time, and the three lattice water molecules had already been released.) A weight loss of 13.51% (calcd. 13.60%) from 50 to 240 °C can be found for the TGA curve for compound 4, which can be attributed to the release of two lattice DMF molecules and two lattice water molecules. The frameworks start collapse at 360 °C.

Gas Uptake Properties

The adsorption and desorption isotherm of N2 were collected under 77 K to check the permanent porosity of compound 3. As shown in  (left), compound 3 exhibits a typical type I adsorption isotherm and absorbs 237.8 cm3⋅g-1 N2 at 77 K which has a microporous characteristic. The BET surface area is 658.7 m2⋅g-1, and the Langmuir surface area is 980.6 m2⋅g-1. Low-pressure CH4 and CO2 uptake was also measured at 273 K. The reversible isotherms are shown in  (right). Compound 3 can absorb 61 cm3 g-1 CO2 and 28 cm3⋅g-1 CH4 at 273 K and 850 mmHg. When the pressure is increased, the adsorption quantity of CO2 increases greater than the adsorption quantity of CH4. It indicates that compound 3 can be used in gas separation of CO2 and CH4. Low-pressure CH4 and CO2 uptake isotherms of , the adsorption quantity of CO2 and the adsorption quantity of CH4 are 46.6 cm3⋅g-1 (273 K and 850 mmHg) and 9.8 cm3⋅g-1 (273 K and 850 mmHg), respectively. The difference value between these two gas uptakes is bigger, which illustrates compound 4 is more suitable for gas separation of CO2 and CH4 than compound 3.
